newsitem.title: JAPAN: JGB yield rise reflects easing pessimism -- BOJ.
newsitem.headline: JGB yield rise reflects easing pessimism -- BOJ.

text.p: The recent rise in Japanese government bond (JGB) yields reflects receding pessimism over the outlook for the economy in Japanese financial markets, a senior Bank of Japan (BOJ) official said on Friday.
The official told Reuters that in general long-term rate rises have a negative impact on the economy.
However, if it the recent rise was a sign that markets have turned more bullish towards the economy, it would be "good news", he said.
"We do not know at which level long-term interest rates will stabilise because their movements have been too rapid," he said.
"However, it seems the rise in the rates was a correction to the widespread pessimism earlier in the financial markets over the economic outlook in the short term and medium to long term," he said.
The yield of the key 3.0 percent 182nd 10-year JGB closed at 2.585 percent on Friday, sharply up from Thursday's 2.510 percent close.
JGB yields have been on an uptrend recently because of growing expectations over a possible change in the BOJ's low interest rate policy following recent advances in Tokyo stocks, traders said.
The key 182nd JGB yield hit a record low for any benchmark 10-year bond of 2.075 percent on April 8.
The yield's fall to a record low followed the release of the BOJ's quarterly "tankan" corporate survey on April 2, which showed sentiment weakening in June.
